135683.question: why does infinity have different sizes?
135683.answer: it's hard to really say that it has an actual 'size', but there are certainly different recipes for infinity that have different qualities. for example, you could say "how many multiples of 3 are there". then you could say "how many multiples of 4 are there" ...... well if the bounds are limitless, then there are an infinite amount of both, but considering in any given limited range there will always be more multiples of 3 than multiples of 4, it would be not quite fair to treat both infinite cases equally

135694.question: I was recently reminded of the tremendous amount of behind-the-scenes work artists/performers/musicians put into their creations, and it hit me how often I take it for granted. And not only time and effort, but also the passion that is poured into their craft; their hearts and souls are deeply invested as well. It's so easy for me to miss that as I take in what is presented at face value. I know it sounds cringingly cliche, but the experience reminded me to be more appreciative and less critical when a creator offers to share their art with me, because it truly is a gift from the heart.
135694.answer: true, but you also have to be honest about whether the thing works for you. there is no shame in admitting that a certain piece of work does not move you. fake appreciation can be a waste of everyone's time, and it is a hard-written law of creativity that different things work for different people, and it can even change for the same person at different times. Although, if you are talking about a situation where an artist personally presents their work directly to you, an audience of 1, and sits there in front of you while you watch it...... that's just a terribly awkward situation that i think everyone should probably avoid

135697.question: so there's been a somewhat recent sequence of events in my life that I'm not sure what to make of. it starts with the bog-standard situation of my brain deciding to develop a crush on someone. I'm pretty shy in general, so unsurprisingly it took me forever to even get comfortable talking to her. it is here that she asks me about my crushes on campus, and after I fumble before asking her back, she tells me about her own crush that rejected her. at this point I consciously force myself to draw the conclusion that it's over. an incredibly common story now that I think about it, but for reasons I still don't understand, I decided to compose a roughly 4 minute piano piece. forever x3 later when said brain's finally gaining back some semblance of normalcy, I once again inexplicably composed. I'm not sure if the specifics are relevant to the question of "why?" why would I mull over sadness, let alone give it form? and why am I proud of them even though their inspiration still invokes sadness? I came across this thing once, that essentially there's infinite everythings. infinite songs, infinite memories, infinite outcomes, infinite nostalgias. it's scary. why do Ihave to choose? I may have only created them as a way of dealing with whatI felt, but why get attached to any of them if there's always infinite more?
135697.answer: .... so you are evidently a writer .....

135699.question: Would you say that superstitions or talismans play a role in your songwriting, even if unintentional? For example, I notice that your songs will sometimes include a statement immediately followed by its negation (eg "i'll never say goodbye / yes i will, but i won't say it tonight", or "i love you / no i don't, yes i do"), which reminds me of my own tendency/compulsion to avoid saying or thinking things that could be misinterpreted as some kind of wish that could have undesired consequences. Like forgetting to roll down the trash can on garbage day and thinking "ugh, I wanna die" but then immediately following it up with "no I don't" just in case a genie or God or something decides to grant my wish. Even if you don't suffer from that particular compulsion, are there any artifacts in your songs that resulted from some sort of superstition?
135699.answer: i think you've presented a stunningly plausible psychoanalysis

135716.question: i'm stuck and isolated. in this one place. metaphorically and literally. for the literally part, it's too difficult to explain why i can't leave. maybe imagine i'm being held at gunpoint to stay. but being stuck is torture, and i'm around people that yell threats at me constantly and occasionally punch me. hold on i'm sorry, that's probably really upsetting to hear. it doesn't feel as bad as it sounds, and my life is pretty chill otherwise. but all of this has messed me up for sure. and it's ruined the one thing i loved and could control, which is art. there's this lack of emotional integrity that comes from being in the kind of environment i'm in. it's repetitive, abusive, and quite numbing. unless i'm mistaken, it'd seem like you need emotional integrity to make original art, but that's not really something i can offer. it's not like i don't want to make art or that i'm not self-motivated to make art, but i don't seem to be able to make art that's truly me or whatever. or like, there's so many ways to make the art and i don't really care which way i do it. i want to care a little more about my art. this problem made me look at other people's art process, but that made me panic about not being like those people instead of someone who can't follow the advice "be yourself". i could if i felt more about what i do than i do. not making art would be sad, making art mostly makes me want to throw up and berate myself for not actually being original or authentic

135768.question: I've been working on a project for the past 1.5 years and I've noticed that whenever I get halfway through I think "oh yeah, I can see the end now, I can totally do this" but then my assurance that I can finish makes the whole thing uninteresting. This is a general pattern with my bigger projects, I tried to prevent it this time by limiting part of the project but I think I just ended up going way deeper instead of way wider. And now in the past couple weeks I couldn't even look at it anymore. I don't think it's that I have trouble finishing things, because I've finished smaller things in the past 1.5 years where I'd spend a month or a few weeks on something and put it out. 135884.question: the ostrogradsky method says you can convert an integral of type 1/W^2 where W is a binomial term with a negative discriminant into (Ax+B)/W + integral of (Cx+D)/W thus reducing a difficult integral that would require a tricky trig sub or a nasty recursive formula into a simpler one that will evaluate to some arctangent with simple transformations. The only annyoing part is finding the constants a, b, c, and d which is achieved by differentiating both sides of the initial equation (integral 1/W^2 =3D Ax+B/W + integral Cx+D/W) multiplying them by W^2, and comparing coefficients next to same terms. for some reasons my analisis class didnt teach me this and instead only showed the nasty recursive formula for situations lime these (this formula can be derived but it takes a long time and memorising it is not an option, besides this isnt what math is about). However they did show us the ostrogradsky method but exclusivly for integrals 1/sqrt(W). I recon it might have been purpesful to see who blindly learns the formula and who tries looking for a better solution by, in this case, applying a known method for a different purpose than it was taught for.I hope my professor will let me use this on an exam without having to prove this identity.

135939.question: want a math problem i thought of? if not you can stop reading. the question is: can you play a valid game of chess where you get back to the starting position, but its BLACKs turn instead of white's in that position? if so give the moves, if not then prove it. i can come back with a hint or the answer if you want.
135939.answer: first we can say pawns can't move because you'd never get them back. that being said, the only thing that can move is a knight, and then the rook can toggle back and forth when the knight is away. now, for the knight to return home, it must make an even number of moves, i claim. because each time the knight moves it switches to a different colored square. so for a knight to get to the same colored square it must make an even number of moves. Ok so what about the knights trading places, well for the knights to trade places, this would require an odd number of moves for each knight, still making an even number of moves in total. The only other thing to move is the rook, but this also will always be an even number of moves, because there is only one available square to toggle to. for the rook to return home it must make an even number of moves. So for everyone to return home, both sides must make an even number of moves. The problem with that: whenever it's black's turn, white has always made 1 more move han black has. which means their move totals can never be both even at the same time (unless it's white's turn). therefore this task seems to be impossible, i believe. i look forward to the humiliation of you telling me you've found a way

135979.question: Why do notes sound "nice" together? I'm familiar with the harmonic series and such, but why would constructive interference sound pleasurable? The only way I can think is that dissonance is harder and harsher, even more painful to listen to so by comparison. This leads into another concept:chromatic gravity. Why does it sound satisfying when dissonance is resolved by frequencies moving by small increments. These questions opens up a whole can of worms pertaining to humanity itself don't you think?
135979.answer: yes, you are getting at a collosally important question, which is how do we do this, what's even good, why is it good, what makes a 'good' musical experience, what makes a good story, what makes a good cinema experience, ..... what is the recipe, what is the rule, what is the formula. [spoiler ahead] what do you wish the formula was? do you enjoy being surprised by what appears to be a new formula? do you ever feel comfort in seeing a familiar formula, but with a twist sometimes? do you suppose it would be fun to sometimes even see someone use a broken formula, or the wrong formula on purpose? do you ever think it would be fun to see a formula work when it shouldn't, or not work when it should? if you answered yes to any of these questions, congratulations it's not a formula. it's you. What's the formula for 'you'? Do you think you could still know who you are without one? Would you prefer it to be easy, complex, or totally paradoxical? would you prefer being able to choose, or would you like to sometimes be surprised? if you answered yes to any of these q sorry out to lunch

136193.question: I really enjoyed the Don't you want me cover with Scary Pockets. In case of such covers, I reckon all the music is prearranged beforehand by an organizing party or someone, but I wonder if and how much freedom you had. Given the level of musicians included and the free-formity of jazz-like vibes, it seems likely (to a barely musician like myself) that you guys didn't need to play the arrangement note for note and some freedoms could be allowed. How was it in the case of drums? Were some parts added by ours truly?
136193.answer: i will tell you exactly how it went. jack was going through a real 'hurry is the only way' mentality phase at that point. he had been brutally stuck on some projects recently and was determined that the only way out was QUICK. so it was just let's get in a room and figure it out within like 20 minutes and actually even start recording it before we've even totally figured it out. but there's also another weird story about the arrangement for that song, because they had sent me the song choices the day before (which they dont normally do, i dont know why they did.) and for some reason, and maybe this is actually a generic choice, but i had the idea to do a purdie shuffle for it, but the weird thing is when ryan picked me up at the airport he said he'd also had the same idea. so me and ryan coincidentally both thought to do a purdie shuffle for it. and then the 4-on-the-floor-reggae thing in the intro i think was my idea, because i noticed that the riff actually sounded kind of like a sort of marley riff when you re-purpose it that way. And then i think to swap in some actual 16ths at the tail end of the riff was jack's idea. But the two governing principles of all the sessions at that time, for those guys, i believe, was 1: try to make it a 'different' style from the original, and 2: wing it at breakneck speed and start recording takes before you've really figured it out

136236.question: can you explain "The Lick"? I keep hearing about it but i don't know much about it. does it have a backstory? is it just a meme with no meaning beyond its memehood? or something else?
136236.answer: that's been around for a long time. somewhere in the 1900s someone noticed that jazz players tend to play this one riff a lot. a friend told me about this maybe 20 years ago, sang what it was, and i was like "oh right. that one. i like that one anyway". i think the general consensus is that it's a common riff but it's actually pretty good anyway. so it's been a meme long before the word 'meme' was a meme. Then, much more recently i saw some youngsters on stage doing a show and one of them threw that in (somewhat gratuitously) and gave a memetastic glance to the bandmates, and i thought to myself "oh nice, here is some social currency that i am already familiar with. how convenient" and since then i continue to use it both by accident and on purpose

136329.answer: i think it's a ridiculous question for totally different reasons than you. to me what you said is also ridiculous. for me the ridiculousness about the "the meaning of life" thing is that it makes it sound like there is supposed to be 1 meaning and purpose for everyone at all times. but the way it seems to me is that there are infinite meanings all the time. new ones, old ones, it's endless. literally everything is meaningful. meaning is inescapable. even little pockets of what may seem like 'meaninglessness' only elevates the surrounding meanings

136366.question: so i was making coffee. had to wash a mug because i don't trust my family to do it yk. so i was out here using soap, making sure the hot water washes off any grime on every part of the mug. but then i realised after a long time of washing it that i didn't get a tea spoon. do you know how much faster it would have been if i washed the tea spoon with the mug?? so i grabbed a tea spoon and it had an uncomfortable amount of food on it, despite having just come out of the dishwasher. i try using hot water and soap, hoping the pressure of the water will be enough to wash the food off but nah i had to use something. sadly that something had to be my hands because i don't trust the sponge. i'd use gloves but we don't have any for some reason. so i have to wash my hands after that. so now i can make coffee, yeah? i put the coffee stuff in, pour hot water and go to the fridge where i saw before a bottle of milk. i grab the bottle of milk and apparently someone thought a drop of milk is enough to do anything with cause i check it and it's empty. literally nothing. that has never happened to me before. i had to drink black coffee cause i already brewed the thing

136433.question: Hi Bill ! I was forced to play piano as a child but had to learn on my own, no classes or teachers. 136433.answer: the advice i always give is you have to make it your own. although you have an interesting situation because you actually did it on your own before. this is the way i would recommend, but i think the huge difference boils down to the fact that someone else wanted you to do it. so in that case you should be all set now. whatever excites you

136446.question: hey! I'm in the process of reinventing the way I write music and I'm curious where you start your writing process. What do you typically start with when writing music?
136446.answer: i start with what level of update i want to be working on. For example: if i'm working on update level zero, i'll come up with some brand new things. If i want to be working on things of update level 1, i'll work on only things that i have come up with before but never updated, and update those things. If i'm working on update level 5, then i'll work on only things that have been updated 5 times (well actually 4 times if you dont count the original inception as an update) i should also mention it's quite often that brand new level 0s come at me out of nowhere sometimes when i wasnt even trying to write. those then get added in and become eligible alongside the other level 1s

136507.question: What's the difference between a connoisseur and an aficionado?

136509.question: what does your average bass fx chain look like? any tips or warnings for people envious of your mixing?

136706.question: what is your aesthetic ideology?
136706.answer: at this point, what comes to mind is: Sometimes as an audience member we may see something and think to ourselves "eh, that was probably faked. or at least if it wasnt, it could have been. or even SHOULD have been, to save time." Regardless of whether the thing was faked or not, this still creates a lousy detached feeling for the audience, just to have been brought to this thought process. So the goal is to find ways to never give the audience that feeling. this might be one of the most exciting creative challenges there ever was, but at the same time it's also an echo of similar challenges at earlier stages in our technological history

136713.question: My process is seemingly so different from yours (as I understand it). You write your songs first on paper in a quiet space, and later actually hear how it sounds on instruments, correct? Like you know in your head what it's going to sound like? To me that seems CRAZY as so much of the writing process TO ME is feeling out what chord best fits next to hit emotionally where I feel the song going, a process that I feel I could never capture abstractly to ever "mathematically" deduce what chord I'm looking for, you know? I'm sure much more music theory will give me more options and allow me better guesses at the next chord, but I could never write a song in my head the same way. (I say "in my head", but of course I mean only hearing it in my head while writing) I guess my question is... are you able to distinguish the emotional impact of the chords you choose, even when not hearing the song as you write it? Do you think of chords in that way, or is it more informed by theory? I would love some insight into that side of your process. How do you know what chords, inversions, voicings, qualities, etc are going to hit how you expect them to when you go to record a song you have written? (Of course this is all built on the assumption that I understand your writing process being done on paper first, and assuming you have all the chords written out, and a melody in mind, before actually playing any notes... please correct me if Iam wrong.) Thanks Bill, love your work :)
136713.answer: that's one of many methods. nowadays i usually have a keyboard with me whoa whoa whoa hold on. Are you able to sit in a quiet room and write down english sentences that you'd want to say, and is there anything 'mathematical' about that? if i couldnt then it certainly would not be safe to write without an instrument. similarly, and i always use the language analogy, if you werent comfortable speaking and writing in english, it would be impossible to coherently write things, such as your question, without speaking them. but, again, like the language analogy, this takes YEARS of experience. this is not something that a person can do in their first few weeks of learning, let's say, their first language. or even their second for the above reasons that question makes no sense to me. i suppose that would strike me as an enormous 'false dichotomy' the same way you know what words to use, which, as i always say, is quite a miracle. the imagination is mysterious and powerful

136748.question: What do you think about songs which repeat the same lyric without ever expanding on the idea of that lyric? Also, what do you think about songs which repeat the same chords or rhythms throughout the entire song without changing them up? Does it feel like the musician is trying to pad out the runtime of their song by minimizing the effort spent composing the song and writing the lyrics, or is there a good reason to keep repeating some parts of a song without variation? Why does it feel like modern songs are just composed of simple loops and lyrics, rather than feeling like every part of the song is unique?
136748.answer: there's a lot to unpack here. first, the golden rule. what one listener might find 'useless and repetitive', another listener might find totally enthralling. and, for a different song, those same two listeners' opinions might even be reversed. totally separate question, do music artists sometimes try to fill out the runtime of songs just because they think it 'should' fill up that much time; probably yes some people do that and i'd be of course wholeheartedly against that and i lecture against it frequently. part of a general anti-should worldview that i probably have, when it comes to creativity. ("should i do this, should i do that, whats the 'correct' way", art suffocates when asked these questions. either it's driving you wild or it's not.) then thirdly you indicated that you are feeling that songmakers currently seem to be generally not living up to your expectations of them. It is perfectly natural and normal to feel this way. And what i always strongly advocate is: use this frustration to fuel your inspiration to do it better. If you truly believe you are onto something that 'most other songmakers' are not, ..... then, ... my goodness what a huge gift that is. this is exactly the kind of scenario that can inspire a whole career

136763.question: this is going to sound incredibly stupid, but. somewhere along the way i mentally tied my physical appearance (especially my youth) to my "deserving" to create art. I made a bit of music i liked, and as i was listening to it i looked in the mirror and saw someone with burgeoning forehead wrinkles and a receding hairline looking back at me, and suddenly i felt like i dont deserve to make art and that it only belongs to people that still have their youth. it felt like i needed to give up on art and just get a boring job and try and start a family or whatever. i understand this is stupid and based on societal expectations and recognizing patterns of young attractive people making music and old people working normal jobs. but. its really affecting my ability to conceptualize myself making art in the future. I keep imagining myself at like 47 strumming the same stupid guitar and playing the same chords and i feel so infantile. i really respect how committed you are to making art for as long as you can be alive, and i feel the same way, it just feels so stupid to have a hang up like this interfere with what i'd ostensibly thought was my life's mission. maybe if im weak enough to let something like aging bother me this much then i wasn't cut out for making art. i dont know. maybe you've felt something similar? sorry about this stupid rambling non-question vent session. also im 23 years old yeah yeah yeah cue laugh track i know i know im young. i just feel old as balls
136763.answer: if i may tell you the opposite side of the story, people who are young and attractive sometimes find themselves in a peculiar situation where they find they have to work twice as hard to convince people they actually have real talent. sometimes they feel they need to overcome the perception that their success is based on looks alone if youre bored with strumming that particular guitar then that has nothing to do with age. if youre having these thoughts then it almost seems like you might be bored with it now already there are so many different ways to go about all these life issues, i dont even think i could list them all. but it seems pretty standard that the biggest and brightest stars of creativity have certainly suffered at least the same insecurities as you've felt. but it seems like this sets up a nice pit of misery to rebel against. which is exactly what your work needs to make it come alive

136799.question: Are you still able to enjoy simple music even though you write pretty complex jazzy stuff? Do you ever listen to Believe by Cher because of how incredible it is, despite being a pretty basic song?
136799.answer: there's a lot to unpack here. you assumed 2 things about the song you mention, as if they are facts "it's incredible" and "it's basic". both those things could be true for some people at some times, but they dont have to be. but then the main question you raise, i think, has to do with complex vs simple and is one or the other better to me, and my answer is no absolutely not. complex and simple are both wonderful. stereotypically i feel there is a prevalent viewpoint out there that complexity ruins music, but then again there's another prevalant viewpoint out there that complains about 'mindless/stupid' music. i basically reject both viewpoints, and i maintain that there is not even any definition of what makes music good, AND, most of the time there's not even any eact definition of what makes something complex or simple. but to get perhaps closer to what you were asking, i do like the song, i dont really think it's basic, but i also do not consider 'basic' an inherently positive OR negative trait, nor is it even definable

136802.question: so i was making some.... shoddy fuckn 2d vid instead of the 3d like i was hopin ykno, cause like the vid was due in.... i dunno a few weeks or maybe days at that point? cant remember. so something about me is that i have an incredible amount of confidence that i can get anything i want to done, in basically any amnt of time. but ths time i was overly ambitious, and at least a little bit stupid. accepted some things i shouldnt have. and with limited 3d experience under my belt i decided to take on 30s of animation, planning to do it 3d. and they needed a bit more help so i volunteered to take on 30s more. now at the time i was really interested in learning maths and physics, and i had to help out the fam with some stuff. so that took up a lot of my time. and i was planning on doing everything; modeling and rigging characters, setting up env stuff, animating it all, everything. but then i realised nearing the due date that i may not be as superhuman as i thought. and they also were rushing me a bit and i felt increasing anxiety that id never get the video done and theyd be disappointed in me. so i spent the whole of 2 days quickly doing a minute of 2d animation with only some 3d scenes where i felt it didnt look out of place. but it's like fuckin hell, i didnt try hard enough. i probably couldve done it if i took it more seriously. i kept sleeping and doing other stuff. i feel guilty for giving some half heartedly made, botched video to these people instead of giving the best animation i could
136802.answer: i dont think you realize how much better your actual result was than what you would have let it turn into if you could have

136803.question: Are you interested in stand up comedy?

136890.answer: out of all the parodoxes found in nature, and in the world, this one is pretty standard. you can just be both. 136914.question: In "just did a bad thing" you said at the end of the song "just did a strange thing, now everything's pink". You also commonly say your songs are based on how it felt to write them. how did everything become pink during the songwriting (whether literally or metaphorically)? Also big fan of your vids, bill
136914.answer: i'll tell you exactly what that is. it's a song ending. it's a very strange thing for a song to end. when you're in the song, the song is the whole world. but eventually the song has to end and you have to transition into the world outside of that song. so song endings, at least for me, often have this weird shocking quality to them, kind of like a vestubule of a building, or a decompression chamber. or that space between the inner and outer wrapper, on a loaf of bread. nevermind, better metaphor, it's like the song is dying. the song ends, so the ending of songs often sounds like the song is being killed. that way a plausible next move for the song at that point would be to no longer be playing

136929.question: Is meh a word or a sound

136930.question: disclaimer: this might come off as more of an existential rant than a question. i love how into songwriting you are. you are among the only people on earth that i really resonate with when they talk about it. but then again, one thing differentiates us two. you actually do it. you put out songs. i understand everything you're talking about when answering these questions, i feel as if i percieve it the same way you do, sometimes i even console myself saying it's what i live for, yet i still don't make music. you give beautiful inspiring insights, yet i still can't regularly put them to use. it means so much to me that it scares me out of it. and it's this constant cycle of wanting it too much and not wanting it enough. sometimes i catch myself in the middle ground with the guitar in my hand but that middle ground is so unpredictable and it throws me off every time it comes by me. it's so short as well. it leaves me dazed, journaling for so long in attempt to uncover what made me land at the sweet spot. i almost always get too self conscious before anything worth sharing feels complete, yet it always gives me a little hope. but it's been 6 years... i've been officially in love with music for the last 6 years. 4 of which i have been in this stagnant state. i convince myself i dont need it. i judge myself when i see others succeed. how do i actually get myself to actually and consistently do it??? how do i balance out wanting it too little and too much on a regular basis??? i love creating so much it genuinely, literally hurts when i'm not doing it. and most of the time i'm not doing it. i'm sorry if this is a bit intense, i don't mean to burden you with any emotions. but if you have any wisdom to share with me, it would be greatly appreciated. thank you for everything you do by the way
136930.answer: all i can say is, one day you will probably find yourself on the other side of this conversation, advising someone who is envious of the things you seemingly so simply just "can do". but of course they'll have no idea what it took you to get there

136936.question: do you remember the way some songs were written when they become relevant to a specific moment in your life? eg. "just did a bad thing", and coping with the fact that you just did a bad thing by remembering your written wisdom on the subject of doing a bad thing
136936.answer: actually what happened on that one was i had narrowed it down to about 20 choices for which song (or song idea) was going to be the next one to finish and record, and that was one of them. it was certainly not my favorite, but it must not have been my least favorite because it made the top 20. that idea itself is not related to any particular bad thing or other, it's just a song idea which i apparently thought was cool when i came up with it. and slightly cool when i picked it for the top 20. Then i started narrowing it down by eliminating ones from the 20, that was probably one of the first to get eliminated, then i kept eliminating them and eventually i got it down to 1, but i didnt really want to do that one either, so i eliminated that one as well. I just sort of frustratedly shrugged and said "well that wasn't the point", and i un-eliminated all of them and then just quickly chose the "bad thing" one, because it was kind of the one that felt the weakest. because the point is that it shouldn't matter which song you choose, any idea can be made good. And the truth is, it can actually be very energizing to work with a weaker idea, because it makes the creative engine turn on stronger, to compensate. and that's certainly what i noticed, after getting started on it and writing the next 8 bars or so. so sometimes i refer to the "bad thing" as the fact that i accidentally eliminated all of my choices and ended up going with the weakest one. Other times, i tell the story that the "bad thing" was that i spent simultaneously too much and too little time on the production of the song, and accidentally spent the exact right amount of time, but that's another story
